sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of travel outcome occurring on a trip
message_1:
A tour company offers 5 different adventure tours. On average, 30% of the people who book a tour choose a hiking trip, 25% choose a river rafting trip, 15% choose a kayaking trip, 20% choose a biking trip, and 10% choose a camping trip. If a group of 10 people books a tour, what is the probability that:

a) Exactly 3 people choose a hiking trip?
b) At least 2 people choose a river rafting trip?
c) More than 1 person choose a camping trip?
message_2:
To solve these problems, we will use the binomial probability formula:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where n is the number of trials (in this case, 10 people booking a tour), k is the number of successes (the number of people choosing a specific tour), p is the probability of success, and C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time.

a) Exactly 3 people choose a hiking trip:

n = 10, k = 3, p = 0.3

P(X = 3) = C(10, 3) * 0.3^3 * (1-0.3)^(10-3)
P(X = 3) = 120 * 0.027 * 0.343
P(X = 3) ≈ 0.2668

b) At least 2 people choose a river rafting trip:

n = 10, p = 0.25

We will find the probability of 0 or 1 person choosing a river rafting trip and subtract it from 1:

P(X ≥ 2) = 1 - P(X = 0) - P(X = 1)

P(X = 0) = C(10, 0) * 0.25^0 * (1-0.25)^(10-0)
P(X = 0) = 1 * 1 * 0.0563
P(X = 0) ≈ 0.0563

P(X = 1) = C(10, 1) * 0.25^1 * (1-0.25)^(10-1)
P(X = 1) = 10 * 0.25 * 0.075
P(X = 1) ≈ 0.1875

P(X ≥ 2) = 1 - 0.0563 - 0.1875
P(X ≥ 2) ≈ 0.7562

c) More than 1 person chooses a camping trip:

n = 10, p = 0.1

We will find the probability of 0 or 1 person choosing a camping trip and subtract it from 1:

P(X > 1) = 1 - P(X = 0) - P(X = 1)

P(X = 0) = C(10, 0) * 0.1^0 * (1-0.1)^(10-0)
P(X = 0) = 1 * 1 * 0.3487
P(X = 0) ≈ 0.3487

P(X = 1) = C(10, 1) * 0.1^1 * (1-0.1)^(10-1)
P(X = 1) = 10 * 0.1 * 0.3874
P(X = 1) ≈ 0.3874

P(X > 1) = 1 - 0.3487 - 0.3874
P(X > 1) ≈ 0.2639

So, the probabilities are:

a) ≈ 26.68%
b) ≈ 75.62%
c) ≈ 26.39%
